title: Editorial: DA ayisafani. What next?
text:
Voices Editorial: DA ayisafani. What next?

In the lead-up to the DA’s federal council meeting, City Press expressed concern that it could be a make-or-break one for the party.

Tensions had been building up steadily and, uncharacteristically for the DA, the party was riven into different blocks that were not prepared to brook any compromise.

Our wish then was that whatever their differences, the country’s official opposition would emerge cohesive so that it would continue to play the crucial role of keeping government in check.

But alas, the party imploded in a way that few had expected. By Wednesday, it did not have a party leader, chief whip, federal chairperson, parliamentary leader or chief executive officer.

The only person left standing was Helen Zille, who had made a spectacular comeback. But her return, supported by a small group of hardcore liberal purists, appeared more like wresting the party back from the direction that Mmusi Maimane was leading to in order to change tack.

Read: Mmusi Maimane was once SA’s most favoured political leader

The facts are contentious, but out there the perception is that Zille and her supporters are motivated more by a need to cater for conservative white voters whom the party has shed to the Freedom Front Plus.

While there is nothing inherently problematic with fighting to retrieve lost votes, it appears to be happening at the expense of consolidating the black support that Maimane was intent on wooing.

To quote Joburg mayor and former DA member Herman Mashaba: “I am gravely concerned that the DA I signed up to is no longer the DA that has emerged out of this weekend’s federal council. I cannot reconcile myself with a group of people who believe that race is irrelevant in the discussion of inequality and poverty in South Africa in 2019.”

But this implosion is now a done deal and the DA, Parliament and South Africa’s democracy are all the weaker for it.

The shortsightedness of those who engineered this can only be great news for those who hate accountability and the strengthening of a strong opposition that is not just content to bark at the governing party, but is actually capable of dislodging it from power if it fails South Africans.

It remains to be seen what will now happen to those who have departed, or will depart, from the DA.

If they do form a new party, what will its identity be?

Will it be just another party adding to the plethora or will it offer South Africans something genuinely new?
